titleproper.value: Guide to the American Veterans for Peace Records <num>TAM 246</num>

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-05-08T19:07:58</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

abstract.value: American Veterans for Peace (AVP) was founded in 1951 to oppose American participation in the Korean War. The AVP opposed militarism and supported improved Soviet relations and a progressive social agenda. The group published <title render="italic">Progressive Veteran</title> (later <title render="italic">Vet's Voice</title>). The collection includes correspondence, ephemera, internal documents, petitions, public statements, and newsletters created by the AVP and other progressive organizations.

p.value: Identification of item, date; American Veterans for Peace Records; TAM 246; Box number; Folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Materials donated by Stanley Turkel in 2001. The accession numbers associated with this gift are 2001.081, 2002.013, NPA.2002.048, and NPA.2005.037.

American Veterans for Peace (AVP), officially founded in June 1951, was the result of a Communist Party-oriented initiative in the months following the outbreak of the Korean War that inspired the founding of several local Veterans for Peace organizations. The AVP published a monthly newsletter, first titled <title render="italic">Progressive Veteran</title> and then renamed <title render="italic">Vet's Voice</title> in 1950. While its main purpose was to oppose American participation in the Korean War, AVP also opposed militarism and supported improved relations with the Soviet Union and a progressive social agenda. Norman Wagner and Paul Green served as co-chairs of the New York chapter of AVP.

The collection contains correspondence, primarily between New York chapter co-chairs Paul Green and Norman Wagner, as well as ephemera, internal documents, and petitions and public statements. It also includes AVP newsletters and the newsletters of other progressive organizations, including foreign veterans' organizations. There are files on two annual AVP events: Elbe River Day, commemorating the meeting of American and Soviet troops in 1945, and AVP's art show (the file includes several photographs). Other materials document the campaign against the 1951 film <title render="italic">Desert Fox</title>; the U.S. Post Office's suppression of <title render="italic">Vet's Voice</title>; the activities of an allied organization, the American Women for Peace (including copies of two issues of its monthly newsletter, <title render="italic">The Peacemaker</title>); and the activities of the Australian Legion of Ex-Servicemen and Women.
